p.s: Statements like Shakespeare never grows old.He continues to inspire each new generation by Norman J. Lund are often and widely discussed.
Shakespeare is often taught at schools, but is it really necessary?
One of the most important arguments for studying Shakespeare in school is the themes he covers in his plays.
They're all relevant themes that everyone can somehow identify with and relate to them, like love, hate, greed, jealousy, ambition and power.
But on the other hand those themes and emotions are all conveyed through an outdated world view, since he lived over 400 years ago.

Similarly, one can argue that those themes can be found in a lot of other works by more modern authors which also cover relevant topics from today like climate change, gender roles, inequality and more.
But this historical relevance of Shakespeare's works can also be a positive aspect since it gives an excellent insight into the minds of people from the 17th century.
It has a historical value and his plays can help students better understand and to grasp the meaning of it.
Another positive effect of ShakespearesShakespeare's popularity are the high numbers of adaptionsadaptations like movies, plays or even books that exist today.
Shakespeare has been an inspiration to a lot of people worldwide and quotes of him can be found everywhere.
Similarly he invented lots of words we now use in our englishEnglish, like assassination for example.
So it could be interesting to study how exactly Shakespeare used those words in his plays.
But in contrast to that, a lot of critics are right to say that the plays were written to be shown on stage and watched by an audience, instead of read and analyzed line by line.
Perhaps the characters came to life when embodied through an actor on stage and interpreted by them.
So the wide variation of adaptionsadaptations today could be what is studied in school instead of Shakespeare's vague and open to interpretation descriptions of characters.
That is another thing interesting about Shakespeare's works.
His characters are vividly human and flawed.
And as such can be interpreted differently and still make every adaptionadaptation unique.
